questions.text: What is the next step in the management of a suspected tubal pregnancy with inconclusive transvaginal ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Serum beta hCG levels

Explanation:

Serial serum beta hCG monitoring is the appropriate next step when transvaginal ultrasound is inconclusive in suspected tubal pregnancy.

  • Serial beta hCG measurements are the first choice investigation for suspected ectopic pregnancy when ultrasound is inconclusive.
  • Normal rise in early viable pregnancy shows doubling of beta-hCG levels over 48 hours
  • Discriminatory zone (1500-2000 mIU/mL) represents the beta hCG level at which a gestational sac should be visible on transvaginal ultrasound
  • Abnormal rise or plateau suggests potential ectopic pregnancy and guides further management

Diagnostic Modality

Findings for Unruptured Ectopic Pregnancy

Beta hCG Levels
  • Failure to double the value of β-hCG in 48 hours
  • Lower concentration of β-hCG than expected for gestational age

Transvaginal Sonography (TVS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac within the uterine cavity when β-hCG ≥ 1500 IU/L.
  • Adnexal Mass: An adnexal mass clearly separate from the ovary (Blob sign).
  • Ring-of-Fire Pattern: Increased blood flow around the ectopic mass on Color Doppler.
  • Presence of pseudo gestational sac.
  • Free fluid in the Pouch of Douglas

Transabdominal Sonography (TAS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac when β-hCG ≥ 6,000 IU/L
  • Other features: May be visible but less sensitive than TVS for smaller masses

 

Methotrexate administration (Option B): Medical management with methotrexate is inappropriate without definitively diagnosing an ectopic pregnancy and ensuring specific selection criteria are met. Methotrexate is contraindicated if there is any possibility of a viable intrauterine pregnancy.

Laparotomy (Option C): Emergency laparotomy is reserved for patients with suspected ectopic pregnancy who are hemodynamically unstable or show signs of acute abdomen. This patient is stable and requires definitive diagnosis before any surgical intervention.

Diagnostic laparoscopy (Option D): While laparoscopy is the definitive diagnostic tool for ectopic pregnancy, it is too invasive as an initial diagnostic step when the patient is stable and diagnosis is unclear. Less invasive options like serial beta hCG monitoring should be exhausted first.

questions.text: In which trimester is the quadruple test performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2nd trimester

Explanation:

  • Quadruple test is performed during 2nd trimester (15-22 weeks).

Prenatal Genetic Screening:

 

First trimester

Second trimester

Timing

11 - 14 weeks

15 - 22 weeks

Screening test

 
  • Dual Test:
    • PAPP-A (Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein-A)
    • Beta-hCG
  • Can be combined with ultrasound measurement of - Nuchal translucency (NT) and nasal bone If NT is ≥ 3 mm in the first trimester
  • Triple Test:
    • Maternal Serum Alpha Fetoprotein (MSAFP)
    • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
    • Beta hCG

OR

  • Quadruple Test:
    • Maternal Serum Alpha Fetoprotein (MSAFP)
    • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
    • Beta hCG
    • Dimeric inhibin-A

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, a second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and a third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

Explanation: The history of recurrent miscarriages and preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia in this G4A3 woman strongly indicates antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:

  • Pathophysiology:
    • APAs or binding β2-glycoprotein-I causes platelet aggregation & endothelial dysfunction → Leading to thrombus formation.
    • Reduced prostaglandin E2, decreased protein C or S activity & increased prothrombin activation.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Venous Thrombosis
    • Arterial Thrombosis: MI, Stroke
    • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia/ thrombocytopenia
    • Renal artery or vein; Glomerular thrombosis
    • Pregnancy:
      • Preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome
      • Recurrent miscarriage
      • Preterm delivery
      • Fetal-growth restriction
      • Fetal death

Diagnosis: Modified Sapporo/Sydney criteria: At least 1 clinical + 1 lab criterion needed for diagnosis.

Clinical Criteria

Laboratory Criteria

Obstetrical:

  • ≥3 unexplained consecutive spontaneous miscarriages < 10 weeks gestation
  • ≥1 unexplained fetal death(s) ≥10weeks' gestation
  • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency necessitating delivery before 34 weeks

Vascular:

  • ≥1 episode of arterial, venous, or small-vessel thrombosis in any tissue
  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant (ISTH guidelines)
  • Medium/high serum levels of IgG or IgM anticardiolipin antibodies
  • Anti-β2 glycoprotein-I IgG or IgM antibody

Management:

APS Subtype

Antithrombotic Therapy

APS with prior thrombosis
  • Start therapeutic LMWH after confirming intrauterine pregnancy. (40 mg enoxaparin daily.)
  • Begin low-dose aspirin (LDA) before or immediately upon pregnancy confirmation. (60 to 80 mg daily)
  • Avoid oral anticoagulants and factor Xa inhibitors throughout pregnancy.

APS with pregnancy morbidity but no prior thrombosis
  • Prophylactic-dose LMWH or unfractionated heparin upon confirmation of pregnancy,
  • LDA (81 mg) as early as possible.

Patients with early or late pregnancy loss
  • Prophylactic-dose LMWH or unfractionated heparin,
  • LDA (81 mg) from before pregnancy or as soon as known

Preeclampsia with severe features or placental insufficiency
  • LDA from before pregnancy or as soon as known,
  • Consider LMWH in specific cases

Hydroxychloroquine: For recurrent pregnancy loss despite standard therapy.

IVIG and Prednisone: For refractory cases to reduce recurrent pregnancy loss; low-dose prednisone is preferred to minimise maternal and fetal risks.

Syphilis (Option A), caused by Treponema pallidum, can lead to adverse pregnancy outcomes like miscarriage or stillbirth. However, the recurrent pregnancy loss pattern described here is not characteristic of syphilis.

TORCH infections (Option C), including Toxoplasma, Rubella, CMV, and HSV, can cause sporadic spontaneous pregnancy loss and congenital abnormalities. However, the recurrent loss and preeclampsia pattern in this case is not typical of TORCH infections.

Gestational diabetic mellitus (Option D) causes complications like fetal growth issues, preterm birth, and preeclampsia, but it is not associated with the recurrent pregnancy loss pattern observed in this case.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient on treatment for infertility came with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and mild vaginal bleeding. Her beta hCG level was 2800 mlU/mL. On ultrasound, a 3cm mass was seen in the left adnexa. It contained a gestational sac with no fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate management for this patient? hCG- Human Chronic Gonadotropin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Single-dose methotrexate

Explanation: The patient's history of infertility treatment, along with amenorrhea, vaginal bleeding, and a beta-hCG value of 28,000 mIU/mL, suggests a possible unruptured ectopic pregnancy, and the most appropriate management is single-dose methotrexate.

Expectant Management: (Option A)

  • Suitable for asymptomatic women with stable or falling β-hCG levels.
  • Predictors of success:
    • Initial β-hCG levels <175 mIU/mL.
    • Significant drop in β-hCG over 48 hours.
    • Sonographic findings of an inhomogeneous mass.
  • Requires close surveillance and emergency care access.

Medical Management: Single or multiple dose of Methotrexate is preferred if:

  • Best candidates are asymptomatic, motivated, and compliant.
  • Predictors of success:
    • Low initial serum β-hCG levels (<5000 mIU/mL).
    • Small ectopic pregnancy size (<3.5 cm).
    • Absence of fetal cardiac activity.
  • Protocols:
    • Single-Dose Protocol: 50 mg/m² MTX intramuscularly.
    • Multidose Protocol: MTX (1 mg/kg) alternates with leucovorin (0.1 mg/kg). Up to four MTX/leucovorin pairs if needed.

Surgical Management:

  • Indications:
    • Hemodynamic instability or tubal rupture.
    • Persistent trophoblast after MTX failure.
  • Procedures:
    • Salpingectomy: (Option C)
      • Removal of the affected fallopian tube.
      • Preferred for ruptured ectopic pregnancies.
  • Salpingostomy:
    • Incision to remove ectopic pregnancy while preserving the tube.
    • Higher risk of persistent trophoblast (5-15%).

Milking of the tube (Option D) is not a recognized treatment for ectopic pregnancy, as it increases the risk of bleeding, tubal damage, and recurrence.

questions.text: What criteria are utilized for the diagnosis of abdominal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Studdiford criteria

Explanation:

  • Abdominal pregnancy refers to the implantation of a fertilized egg outside the uterus in the abdominal cavity. It is a rare and potentially life-threatening condition. The diagnosis of abdominal pregnancy can be challenging due to its rarity and varied clinical presentations. However, certain criteria have been established to aid in its diagnosis.

The Studdiford criteria are a set of criteria used for diagnosing abdominal pregnancy. These criteria include:

  • Absence of uterine pathology: The absence of any uterine abnormality that could explain the ectopic pregnancy, such as uterine rupture or previous uterine surgery.
  • Demonstration of a live fetus or placental tissue within the abdomen: This can be confirmed through imaging techniques like ultrasound or MRI, which show the presence of the fetus or placenta outside the uterus.
  • The fetus or placenta being separate from other abdominal organs: The fetus or placenta is not attached to any other abdominal organ and can be clearly differentiated from surrounding structures.

 

The Spiegelberg criteria (Option A) are used for diagnosing tubal ectopic pregnancy, not abdominal pregnancy.

The Rubin criteria (Option B) are also used for diagnosing tubal ectopic pregnancy, not abdominal pregnancy.

The term "ring of fire" (Option D) is not a recognized criterion for diagnosing abdominal pregnancy. It may refer to the sensation of burning or intense pain felt during childbirth, particularly during the crowning stage.

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test came with complaints of lower abdominal pain and moderate PV bleeding. She was hemodynamically stable. On USG, there was no gestational sac in the uterus. Ovaries were normal, and no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next line of management?

choices.text: Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Follow-up with beta- HCG

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the absence of a gestational sac in the uterus, along with vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal pai,n raises suspicion of an ectopic pregnancy. The next step would be to follow up with beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-HCG) levels to monitor the trend. Serial measurements of beta-HCG can help determine whether the pregnancy is viable or if it is likely an ectopic pregnancy.

 

A complete abortion (Option A) refers to the passage of all products of conception. However, in this case, the absence of a gestational sac and the symptoms of pain and bleeding suggest the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy, which requires further evaluation.

Given the suspicion of an ectopic pregnancy, admission and observation (Option B) may not be sufficient as it could lead to a delay in appropriate management.

Diagnostic laparoscopy (Option C) may be considered if the patient's condition deteriorates or if there is evidence of hemoperitoneum or signs of rupture. However, it is not the initial step in the management of suspected ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: What recommendation would you provide to alleviate leg cramps for a pregnant woman experiencing discomfort?

choices.text: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Extend knee and dorsiflex foot

Explanation:

  • To alleviate an acute leg cramp, patients should actively contract the muscle group opposite to the one affected in order to stretch it. So, a calf cramp can be relieved by dorsiflexing the foot while keeping the knee extended. This commonly suggested method usually offers quick relief from the cramp.

 

Flexing the knee (bending the leg) and dorsiflexing the foot (Option B) may not provide relief for leg cramps. This position can actually exacerbate the cramping sensation by further contracting the muscles.

While extending the knee is recommended, plantar flexing the foot (pointing the toes downwards) may not be effective in relieving leg cramps (Option C). Plantar flexion primarily involves the calf muscles, which may not directly address the cramping muscles.

Flexing the knee and plantar flexing the foot (Option D) may not provide relief for leg cramps. This position may even contribute to muscle tightness and increase discomfort.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with painful vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. On USG, a well-formed gestation ring with central echoes from the embryo indicates a healthy fetus, and there is observation of fetal cardiac motion. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Threatened abortion

Explanation:

  • The presence of vaginal bleeding in the first trimester along with a healthy fetus observed on USG, indicated by a well-formed gestation ring, central echoes from the embryo, and fetal cardiac motion, is characteristic of a threatened abortion. The cervix is typically closed in such cases, and the pregnancy may still continue successfully with appropriate care.

Clinical Classification of Spontaneous Abortion

Characteristic

Threatened

Inevitable

(Option A)

Incomplete

(Option C)

Complete

(Option D)

Missed

Presentation

Vaginal bleeding in < 20 weeks

Vaginal bleeding or membrane rupture in < 20 weeks

Expulsion of some products of conception

Cervix closed after conception product expulsion

No symptoms

Cervical OS

Closed

Open

Open

Closed

Closed

USG Findings

Normal intrauterine pregnancy with fetal heartbeat

Dilated cervix with sac low in the uterine cavity or cervical canal

Empty gestational sac or retained products of conception

Empty uterus with no retained products of conception

Absence of fetal heartbeat and/or absent growth of gestational sac

Management

Rest, monitor fetal viability

Prepare for inevitable expulsion

Evacuation of retained products of conception

Observation

Surgical evacuation or expectant management

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect concerning medical termination of pregnancy?

choices.text: Baby with serious mental or physical abnormality

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) When the family is large

Explanation:

  • When the family is large The size of the family alone is not a valid medical or legal indication for the termination of pregnancy. The decision for termination must be based on health risks, fetal abnormalities, or other more pressing medical or social factors, rather than family size
  • Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) is generally allowed for specific medical, social, or legal reasons. The criteria for MTP vary by jurisdiction.

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act:

  • The original act was passed in 1971 and amended in 2021.
  • Indications:
    • Maternal Risk
    • Fetal Risk: Spina bifida, Down syndrome. (Option C)
    • Eugenic Conditions: Risks to both mother and fetus.
    • Humanitarian Cause: Pregnancy resulting from rape. (Option A)
    • Contraceptive Failure. (Option D)
  • Qualifications:
    • MBBS, MD/DNB/DGO
    • MBBS who has trained in gynaecology for 6 months
    • MBBS who has performed 25 MTPs under supervision
    • ASHA and AYUSH cannot perform MTP.
  • Additions of 2021 amendment:
    • Abortions allowed up to 20-24 weeks.
    • <20 weeks - Single doctor’s decision; 20-24 weeks - 2 doctors.
    • Extension of abortion rights to single, unmarried females.
    • Inclusion of marital rape under the MTP Act.
    • Abortions >24 weeks in cases of significant fetal anomalies with no gestational upper limit, are to be decided by a state medical board (gynecologist, pediatrician, radiologist).

Gestational Age

Abortive method

Up to 7 weeks

Medical Abortion. (99% success rate if done before 7 weeks)

 

Up to 9 weeks

Up to 10 weeks
  • Medical Abortion
  • Suction evacuation

Up to 12 weeks
  • Suction evacuation
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)

12-20 weeks

Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)

20-24 weeks
  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Prostaglandin Induction.

>24 weeks

Hysterotomy

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding UTI in pregnancy?

choices.text: It is lower in people with sickle cell trait
The preferred antibiotic in pregnancy is amoxicillin
If ASB is not treated, 75% of them will develop symptomatic infection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) If ASB is not treated, 75% of them will develop symptomatic infection

Explanation:

  • Untreated asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) in pregnancy can progress to symptomatic urinary tract infections (UTIs), significantly increasing the risk of complications such as pyelonephritis, preterm labor, and low birth weight. Therefore, routine screening and prompt treatment of ASB during pregnancy are essential to ensure maternal and fetal well-being.

Asymptomatic Bacteriuria (ASB)

  • ≥10^5 CFU/mL of a single bacterium in urine without UTI symptoms.

Causative organisms: E. coli, Klebsiella, Enterococcus, Proteus.

Risk factors: Female sex, age, diabetes, pregnancy, urinary tract abnormalities, catheters, immunosuppressive conditions.

Diagnosis: Urine culture: ≥10^5 CFU/mL without symptoms.

Management:

  • Pregnant women: Requires treatment (e.g., nitrofurantoin, amoxicillin).
  • Non-pregnant women: Generally, no treatment unless symptomatic.
  • Elderly and catheterized patients: Treatment is usually not recommended unless symptomatic.

Complications:

  • Pyelonephritis
  • Preterm delivery
  • Low birth weight
  • Antibiotic resistance

Prevention: Pregnancy screening at 12–16 weeks.

 

The prevalence of ASB is 50% (Option A): The prevalence of ASB during pregnancy is not as high as 50%. It is typically estimated to be around 5-10%.

It is lower in people with sickle cell trait (Option B): Sickle cell trait does not reduce the risk of UTIs in pregnancy. In fact, individuals with sickle cell trait may have a higher risk of developing infections due to compromised renal function.

The preferred antibiotic in pregnancy is amoxicillin (Option C): While amoxicillin is safe in pregnancy and commonly used, the choice of antibiotics is guided by culture sensitivity results and local resistance patterns. Nitrofurantoin and cephalexin are also frequently used.

questions.text: For medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), the opinion of two doctors is required at which gestational age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 20-24 weeks

Explanation:

According to the MTP Act, medical termination of pregnancy between 20-24 weeks of gestation requires the opinion of two registered medical practitioners.

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act:

  • The original act was passed in 1971 and amended in 2021.
  • Indications:
    • Maternal Risk
    • Fetal Risk: Spina bifida, Down syndrome.
    • Eugenic Conditions: Risks to both mother and fetus.
    • Humanitarian Cause: Pregnancy resulting from rape.
    • Contraceptive Failure.
  • Qualifications:
    • MBBS, MD/DNB/DGO
    • MBBS who has trained in gynaecology for 6 months
    • MBBS who has performed 25 MTPs under supervision
    • ASHA and AYUSH cannot perform MTP.
  • Additions of 2021 amendment:
    • Abortions allowed up to 20-24 weeks.
    • <20 weeks - Single doctor’s decision; 20-24 weeks - 2 doctors. (Option A)
    • Extension of abortion rights to single, unmarried females.
    • Inclusion of marital rape under the MTP Act.
    • Abortions >24 weeks in cases of significant fetal anomalies with no gestational upper limit, are to be decided by a state medical board (gynecologist, pediatrician, radiologist).

 

Gestational Age

Abortive method

Up to 7 weeks

Medical Abortion. (99% success rate if done before 7 weeks)

 

Up to 9 weeks

Up to 10 weeks
  • Medical Abortion
  • Suction evacuation

Up to 12 weeks
  • Suction evacuation
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)

12-20 weeks

Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)

20-24 weeks
  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Prostaglandin Induction.

>24 weeks

Hysterotomy
